cheatsheet.title: Create Model from Flat File Source

intro.description: This cheat sheet shows you how to create a model from a flat file source.

description.b: Follow the steps below to create a Teiid Model Project

subitem.label: Launch New Teiid Model Project Wizard

subitem.description:
1) Specify unique project name
2) Click Next > twice to get to Model Project Options page
3) Check folders you wish the wizard to create in your project
4) Click Finish

item.title: Create New Flat File Source Connection

description.b: Follow the steps below to create a Teiid Flat File Connection profile

subitem.label: Launch New Flat File Source Connection Wizard

subitem.description:
1) Specify unique name and optional description and click Next >
2) Browse to select local file folder or enter file folder URL
3) Select desired options and click Finish

item.title: Create Source From Flat File Connection

description.b: Follow the steps below to create a relational model by importing table data via a Flat File connection profile

subitem.label: Launch Import Flat File Source Wizard

subitem.description:
1) Select your Data File Source (connection profile)
2) The Available Data Files section will show your source file location and list your source text files
3) Select a file as your source
4) Browse to select your target source model location and enter unique name. Click Next >
5) Specify your file data format as Character delimited or Fixed width. Next >

Character Delimited Parser Settings Option
The primary purpose of this importer is to help you create a view table containing the transformation required to query the user-defined data file. This page presents a number of options you can use to customize the Generated SQL Statement
1) Specify header options (Column names in header, header line number and first data line number)
2) Parse selected row, changed character delimiter and edit the TEXTTABLE() function options.
3) If columns names are not defined in a file header or if you wish to modify or create custom columns, you can use the ADD, DELETE, UP, DOWN to manage the column info in your SQL.
--- NOTE: To aid in determining if your parser settings are correct you can select a data row in your File Contents Preview section and click the Parse Selected Row button. A dialog will be displayed showing the list of columns and the resulting column data. If your column data is not what you expected, you'll need to adjust your settings accordingly.
4) Click Next >

Fixed Column Width Parser Settings Option
1) Use the File Contents Preview to analyze your column data format
2) Enter your first data line number in the Format Options section.
3) Use the Cursor Position and Text Length value (for selected text) to assist in determing the data column width values in the Column Information in the lower right.
4) If columns names are not defined in a file header or if you wish to modify or create custom columns, you can use the ADD, DELETE, UP, DOWN to manage the column info in your SQL.
5) Set appropriate TEXTTABLE() function options
6) Click Next >

View Model Definition
1) Select the target folder location where your new view model will be created
2) Enter unique view model name
--- Note the Model Status section which will indicate the validity of the model name, whether the model exists or not. Lastly, enter a unique, valid view table name.
4) Click Finish to generate your models

description.b: Follow the steps below to preview data from your newly generated Flat File view table.

subitem.description:
1) Click the browse "..." button to select the newly created view table
2) Click OK to execute the query
3) Results of the query will displayed in the SQL Results view

description.b: Follow the steps below to create a new VDB

subitem.description:
1) Select "..." button to browse and select project or folder location.
2) Enter a unique name for your VDB
3) Enter an optional description for your VDB
4) Select the Add button to choose models to go in your VDB
5) Click Finish

description.b: Follow the steps below to test the VDB

subitem.description:
1) Select "..." button to browse and select a VDB.
2) Click OK to deploy VDB and open connection in Data Source Explorer
3) Follow instructions in open SQL Scrapbook Editor
4) View your query results in the SQL Results view
